div1.p:
Says Cuba Disregarded Treaty
Obligations After 1902.

Cubans Did Not Keep the Island
Clean--Evil Sanitary Condition Can-
not Be Cured This Year--Water-
works and Drainage Necessary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20.--Mr. Ma-
goon, the provisional governor of
Cuba, has reported to the government
here that the outbreak of yellow fever
in Cuba is due to the woeful neglect
of sanitary precautions and a disre-
gard on the part of the Cuban repub-
lic of the treaty obligations to keep
the island clean after the withdrawal
of the American government of inter-
vention in 1902.

The report says that the evil sani-
tary condition cannot be cured this
year despite the most vigorous efforts
and says that the efforts to stamp
out the fever has received little sup-
port from the Cuban physicians.

Governor Magoon says that it will
be impossible to eliminate the yellow
fever at Cienfuegos until after the
completion of the waterworks and
drainage systems and that he hopes
to have completed the waterworks
and sewerage systems in ten or fif-
teen cities on the island within a few
months.

GREAT REDUCTION IN NUMBER
OF CASES AT CIENFUEGOS.

Major Kean Holds Unsanitary Condi-
tion of Place Responsible for the
Fever Outbreak.

CIENFUEGOS, Aug. 20.--The ex-
citement caused by the outbreak of
fever in this city is subsiding, only
eight cases being reported today.
equally divided between Spaniards
and Americans. Meanwhile prepara-
tions for the complete sanitation of
the city are going on, and the causes
of the outbreak are being thoroughly
looked into.

Under the management and direc-
tion of Major Kean and Captain
Thomason, the work of draining the
city will begin within a few days.
Major Kean gave out a statement to
the Cienfuegos press this morning in
which he asserted that he had found
great deficiencies in the sanitary con-
ditions of the city, owing, not to any
lack of ability or efficiency on the
part of the sanitary authorities, but
to the lack of water and sewerage.

Major Kean was invited by the
mayor to make a tour of inspection
through those sections of the city
which are foci of infection and where
the deadly germs of the disease are
bred.

Major Kean accepted the invitation,
and also promised to visit the Cande-
laria Springs, which are today the
only source of water supply for the
city. The water from these springs
is asserted by many to be the cause
of the present conditions. It has been
suggested that Major Kean take with
him a sample of this water that it
may be submitted to a thorough chem-
ical analysis.

It is considered by many that the
investigation now carried on by the
sanitary authorities will hasten the
realization of the project for bring-
ing the Hanabanilla water and the
paving and sewerage of the city, a
project which has been long held in
abeyance through the baneful influ-
ence of local politics.
